question: Question_10
sols:
Use the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic to write

$\displaystyle a = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{e_{i}}$

and

$\displaystyle b = \prod_{i=1}^{m}p_{i}^{f_{i}}$

where we use all the same primes above in the two expansions so we will
allow the possibility of $\displaystyle e_{i}$ or $\displaystyle f_{i}$
to be 0 (but of course not both). Then

$\displaystyle \gcd(a,b) = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})}$

and

$\displaystyle \text{lcm}(a,b) = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\max(e_{i},f_{i})}$.

Now, we have

\begin{align*}
\gcd(a,b)\text{lcm}(a,b) &= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})}\prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\max(e_{i},f_{i})} \\
&= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})+\max(e_{i},f_{i})} \end{align*}

As

$\displaystyle \min(e_{i},f_{i})+\max(e_{i},f_{i}) = e_{i} + f_{i}$

we have that

\begin{align*}
\gcd(a,b)\text{lcm}(a,b) &= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})}\prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\max(e_{i},f_{i})} \\
&= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})+\max(e_{i},f_{i})} \\
&= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{e_{i}+f_{i}}\\
&= \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{e_{i}}\prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{f_{i}}\\
&= ab\end{align*}

completing the proof.
